column6: Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
column13: Goodman has an Anti-Bribery and Corruption Policy, which sets out its commitment to conducting business following applicable laws and regulations in a way that will maintain and enhance its reputation in the market. Goodman prohibits any activity that seeks to bribe, corrupt or otherwise improperly influence a public official in any country or to act (or omit to act) differently from that official's proper duties, obligations and standards of conduct.
column20: Anti-Bribery and Corruption Policy, reputation, market

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: Goodman's Code of Conduct provides the ethical and legal framework for its people in conducting Goodman's business. The Code requires compliance with all legal requirements, ethical expectations and fundamental human rights and details the whistleblowing mechanisms in place to report any ethical concerns.
column20: Code of Conduct, legal framework, human rights

column6: Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
column7: Goodman does not record any instances of corruption.

IUCN Red List species and national conversation list species with habitats in areas affected by operations
column13: In New Zealand, ngahere (native forests) support a diverse array of Indigenous plants, trees, and wildlife. Goodman's New Zealand business planted around 10,700 native plants across 11,000 sqm at its Highbrook Business Park and Roma Road Estates to contribute to its preservation. Species include Manuka, Koromiko, flax and cabbage trees, with about 37 per cent able to grow to five metres or more, helping with canopy cover.
column20: Ngahere, Indigenous plant, Highbrook Business Park

column6: IUCN Red List species and national conversation list species with habitats in areas affected by operations
column13: The 8,000-hectare Collserola National Park is just 15 minutes from the city centre and one kilometre from Goodman's Molins de Rei facility. Yet with open spaces surrounding the park in decline Ã¢ÂÂ as well as ponds and wetlands Ã¢ÂÂ amphibian species were in perilous decline too, the Spadefoot Toad especially. In response, Goodman funded 'the Spadefoot Toad project' managed by the Catalan Society of Herpetology in collaboration with the Collserola Natural Park Consortium. Water quality and vegetation were analysed, and 17 ponds were dug to create perfect breeding conditions before releasing 1,317 larvae and 18 tadpoles.
column20: Spadefoot Toad project, Collserola National Park, Catalan Society of Herpetology
